So who's better to introduce it than Simon himself? Yeah, thank you. The CAP MCP plugin is basically a plugin that allows you to handle model context protocols for your OData service directly in CAP. It's PluginPlay. And yeah, check out the link and description. All right. Hope to talk to you soon. Bye.

[Rekha] Hello, everybody. Are you looking to step up your central point of entry user experience from SAP Build Work Zone Standard Edition, which was previously called SAP Fury Launchpad to SAP Build Work Zone Advanced Edition on SAP BTP? Then here is an in-depth structured guidance to achieve the same. In this blog post written by our SAP Build Works on Product Manager Yumna Abbasi, you could understand the overview of SAP Build Works on Standard Edition and SAP Build Works on Advanced Edition. The key differences between these two offerings, information regarding the subscription and service plans, end-to-end transition path. Under transition, crucial steps like accessing the current implementation, planning the migration, exporting the content, setting up SAP billboards on advanced edition, content migration, how to use the existing configurations, best practices to follow during implementation, testing, validation, change management, and go live are well documented. Get ready to provide your business users a multimedia rich user experience with SAP Build WorkZone Advanced Edition. For more details, refer to the blog post. Link is provided in the description box. Thank you.

[Shila,Sheena & Shrini] It was a good mix of SAP customers and partners, making it a true community event. How was your experience, Sheena? It was great, Shilpa. And what I loved the most is that they follow our SAP developers YouTube channel and they like our content. That's so cool, right? And where are you heading next? So I'm heading to Kuala Lumpur first, where Shini will join me. And then we'll both fly together to Bangkok for the next set of code jams. Good luck. Thank you. We are in the SAP Thailand office in Bangkok, where we just finished SAP Gen AI Code Jam. Before coming here, we were in Kuala Lumpur, where we conducted the SAP Build Code Jam. So, Shirni, how did you feel about the SAP Code Jam Roadshow across Southeast Asia? This is the first time we are doing a Code Jam in this region. We've had many of our SAP developers from our customers and partners attend these events. It was exciting to hear their feedback and discuss the latest innovations happening in the BTP space, especially on SAP Gen AI topics. So, yeah, it was interesting, Code Jam. So, Sheena, what is happening next week? Yeah, the team is having a jam-packed schedule with Antonio traveling to India to join Ajay for the next set of integration suite Code Jam Roadshow across various locations in India. So, stay tuned for further updates.

entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Laura Schmitz - July 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You might have seen our iterations of recognizing active authors (one / two / three / four / five / six)  in SAP Community. We also want to introduce the team behind the SAP Community platform. This month we want to introduce @lauraschmitz  to you which I interviewed recently. Read more about how she got started and what her day to day looks like behind the scenes of the SAP Community.


Marco Santos (MS): I'm super happy that you've decided to join us today. Laura, thank you so much for being here. It's a great pleasure to feature you as our next Community Team Member Spotlight on SAP Community.

Laura Schmitz: Thank you, Marco! I'm also very delighted to be part of this interview. I really appreciate the opportunity.

MS: Awesome. All right, let’s start with an easy one. How did you originally get involved with the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: I got involved with the SAP Community through my second role at SAP. I originally joined the company as a working student in 2018, supporting the learning organization. After finishing my studies in 2020, I applied internally for a Community Advocate role and that’s when I really started getting to know the SAP Community. I’d heard about it now and then in my first role, but I hadn’t really interacted with it until I joined the team.

MS: That’s great to hear! So, you've been on the team for a few years now, but could you tell us a bit more about your current role on the community team and what your day-to-day typically looks like?

Laura Schmitz: Sure! My current role is Community Event Lead, which means I focus on the strategy and overall concept of community events globally. A big part of my job is helping event organizers by supporting them with everything they need to run successful events for their local communities. I also make sure that these efforts are aligned with our broader SAP Community strategy.

MS: Sounds like a big responsibility!

Laura Schmitz: It definitely keeps things exciting! There’s no such thing as a completely typical day, but a common task is reviewing applications from people who are interested in becoming event organizers. I run interviews with them, guide them through onboarding, and ensure any new locations they represent are properly added to our platform.

MS: So you’re kind of a matchmaker for new communities?

Laura: That’s a good way to put it! I also proactively look into regions we haven’t reached yet and try to find engaged community members who might want to help build something there. Beyond that, I stay in regular contact with existing organizers by discussing their upcoming events, helping them with financial or promotional support, and looking for opportunities for our community team to be present at those events as well.

MS: That already sounds like a very full day! All right, let’s move on to the next question. Can you share a particularly memorable moment from your time working with the community?

Laura Schmitz: That would definitely be attending my very first SAP Inside Track. It was in ‘s-Hertogenbosch, in the Netherlands, back in 2022.

It was really special for me because I had joined the community team during COVID. Everyone kept telling me how amazing these events were, and I saw pictures and posts, but I never truly understood what made them so great until I experienced one myself.

The vibe was just incredible! So casual and fun, but also filled with value and genuine knowledge-sharing. And what stood out the most was how welcoming everyone was. People were just happy to connect, learn, and share with each other. I’ll never forget that experience of finally understanding what community is about.

MS: Yeah, I definitely agree. Meeting people in person: nothing beats that for really understanding what a community is all about.

Now, moving on to the next question: You're in contact with many event organizers and community members. How do you stay in touch with community needs and feedback?

Laura Schmitz: Since my focus is mainly on community events, most of the feedback I receive comes directly from the event organizers. They know they can always reach out, often via email, but we also have a dedicated private group on the SAP Community platform. It’s our main space for communication, resource sharing, and best practice exchange. And it also acts as a feedback channel.

In addition to that, we meet on a quarterly basis with all organizers globally. During those sessions, we share updates, but more importantly, we listen to their needs and concerns. We try our best to address their feedback, even if we can’t act on every single request. For me, having that close, open, and transparent relationship with the organizers is really essential.

Marco Santos: That’s great to hear. Sounds like a very organic and ongoing way to stay in touch with what’s happening on the ground. All right, next up: what do you enjoy most about working on the SAP Community?

Laura Schmitz: It’s definitely the people! Connecting with people. Of course, I spend a lot of time being online, behind the scenes and working on the platform, but what really brings me joy is the one-on-one interaction. Whether it's working with a group of organizers in a specific city or hearing about someone’s journey, those connections are what make this role so meaningful.

Every local community is different. Every organizer team has their own way of doing things. That diversity, that authenticity, is what I find so special about this work.

MS: That’s great to hear and a lovely answer! We’ve talked a lot about the past and how you got involved in the community. Now, let’s talk about the future: What’s one thing you’d love to see more of in the SAP Community going forward?

Laura Schmitz: More in-person connections among community members, and continuous relationship building between our team and community members. That’s definitely something I’d love to see continuing and growing. And also adding new locations to the map, we still have some regions that aren’t yet represented in our community. A great example is the Middle East, which has recently started getting involved with their very first SAP CodeJam in Dubai. Now, the organizer wants to establish more community events in the region and connect people on a regular basis. I’d love to see that trend continue. The more local communities we can support, the better.

MS: Sounds like a solid plan. More events, more locations leads to more connection! Okay, and now to wrap things up: Is there anything else you’d like to share with the audience? Anything we didn’t cover that you’d like to add?

Laura Schmitz: I’d like to encourage community members to get active and to engage in their local community - by joining a community event near you or organize your own. There’s a common misconception that you need to be a professional organizer, an expert, or someone with years of experience to lead something meaningful in your community. But the truth is - anyone can start. Real impact often begins with simple actions: a shared interest and a handful of people who just want to connect. And if this this resonates with you and you feel inspired to take that first step, we’d love to hear from you, so reach out and let’s explore what we can build together.

MS: That’s a perfect way to close it out. Thank you so much, Laura, for joining me today: sharing your journey, your day-to-day, and your vision for the future of the SAP Community. It was great having you here.

Laura Schmitz: Thanks again, Marco. It’s been a pleasure!

entry.title: Raja Gupta
entry.content:
More about Raja Gupta in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Raja Gupta
Location (City, Country): Bangalore, India
Occupation: Solution Architect, SAP

 


Raja, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I'm Raja Gupta, a solution architect with over 17 years of experience in SAP. Throughout my career, I’ve led multiple implementation projects and currently work with SAP Partners to co-innovate and build solutions using BTP and AI.

I'm also the author of several SAP-focused books, a regular speaker at global SAP events, and an active contributor to the SAP community through mentoring, blogging, and training. You can find the list of all my books on SAP-Press site  and read of my blogs on SAP Community.

What truly drives me is the joy of sharing knowledge - whether it’s through writing, speaking, or engaging with my 43K+ LinkedIn followers on topics around SAP and AI.

I’m based out of Bangalore. When I’m not working, I’m usually spending time with my kids and family, reading, or planning our next family trip.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I specialize in SAP BTP, SAP Business AI, Joule, Generative AI, and related technologies.

I work closely with SAP Partners to onboard them to SAP Business AI and Joule, guiding them in building real-world solutions. I deliver technical workshops and enablement sessions across various SAP Business AI and BTP topics, often customized for partner-specific needs.

My day typically involves hands-on collaboration with partners, activating SAP Business AI, addressing technical challenges, and enabling partners to adopt SAP’s latest innovations effectively.

Outside of that, I regularly write, train, and mentor within the SAP ecosystem, sharing insights through blogs and community platforms.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

I started engaging with the SAP Community in 2016, when I published my first blog post. What began as a simple attempt to share a few thoughts quickly turned into something much more meaningful — I found a space where people supported each other and where learning didn’t feel one-sided.

Over time, I’ve learned a lot from this community, and that naturally created a sense of responsibility to contribute in return. Whether it’s writing blog posts, speaking at events, or simply answering a question, I’ve seen the real impact of open knowledge-sharing.

As someone who spends a lot of time delivering trainings, and enablement sessions, the SAP Champion role felt like a natural extension of what I already do. It allows me to stay connected with the community, support peer learning, and continue contributing in a more focused and visible way.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

Each morning, I spend the first 30 minutes of my workday either reading something new or drafting content to share with the community. This small but consistent routine keeps me in sync with what’s happening, and also pushes me to contribute back regularly.

I’ve made the SAP Community a regular part of my learning routine. I follow a set of topics closely and make it a habit to visit their pages frequently to stay updated. I’ve also subscribed to SAP newsletters and topic-specific notifications. These notifications helps me to check in and explore new posts, questions, and discussions.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

Here are three things that have worked well for me and might help others get more value from the SAP Community:

Follow topics that genuinely interest you.
Don’t try to keep up with everything. Pick a few areas you're working on or curious about and make it a habit to check their pages regularly. The focused approach helps you stay updated without getting overwhelmed.

Build a simple weekly rhythm.
You don’t need hours. Even spending 15–30 minutes a day reading a blog post, answering a question, or sharing a quick thought can keep you connected and sharp. I personally begin my day with this and it keeps me in sync with what's moving in the ecosystem.

Look beyond the screen.
There’s real value in attending SAP Community events for example SAP Inside Track, CodeJam etc. These are great places to meet others working on similar things, ask questions you wouldn’t post online, and build lasting connections.

Raja's question to you:
If you could give one piece of advice to someone new to the SAP Community, what would it be — and why?

entry.title: Antonio de Ancos
entry.content:
More about Antonio de Ancos in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Antonio de Ancos
Location (City, Country): Madrid, Spain
Occupation: Consultant and Instructor

 

 


Antonio, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

I am a lifelong learner and an “occasional” teacher. I believe we live in an age where all kinds of knowledge are at our fingertips, which can sometimes be overwhelming; that’s why my main work is helping others learn faster and more easily. I enjoy sharing good meals with friends, playing sports, and diving into a great book.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I started in 1997 programming ABAP, specifically in the HR module. From there I explored the entire functional side without ever leaving the technical world behind, which led me to wrestling with SAP BTP since its early days (HCP, SCP…). I’ve been an official SAP instructor for over 20 years in both HCM and Technology areas.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?


I didn’t do anything special to become an SAP Champion; someone nominated me, and here I am 😉. I suppose it has something to do with the content I’ve been creating in Spanish over the years—through my blog (www.aancos.com), social media, and a couple of podcasts where I share my professional journey (www.memoriasdeunconsultor.com) and chat with ecosystem experts (www.hablamosdesap.com), including several SAP Champions.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

In SAP Community I learn from others, since there are people with deep expertise in many of the areas I’m interested in. I find it always easier to learn when someone guides you, although I don’t follow a strict routine.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

I think it’s important to clearly identify a few key thought leaders and accept that you can’t keep up with everything—you risk getting lost in the vast ocean of knowledge. Often, less is more; knowing where to focus is essential.

Antonio's question to you:
Here’s my thought-provoking question: English is undoubtedly the universal language in the technical world, and in SAP in particular (with all due respect to German), so why not create more content for the Spanish-speaking community in their own language?

🌟Клієнти BTP демонструють кращі результати: на 3% нижчі операційні витрати та в 4 рази вища цифрова зрілість порівняно зі звичайними клієнтами SAP.

🔄Ці організації обробляють неймовірні $51 трильйон торгівельного обороту щорічно, з вражаючим охопленням галузей:

  • 90% доходів автомобільної галузі
  • 83% доходів галузі товарів для дому

💼Середньостатистичний клієнт SAP використовує 11 продуктів BTP, а підприємства Азійсько-Тихоокеанського регіону лідирують у впровадженні із середнім показником 19 продуктів!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow in India - recap
entry.content:
What an eventful week it was! (No pun intended)..... Together with @ajay_soreng, we did one SAP CodeJam per day - 3 different cities (Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Bengaluru), 5 different locations, 3 different topics (SAP Integration Suite, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh).

Everything was planned to perfection but I had a mental misstep. I mistakenly thought that there was a visa on arrival when traveling to India when in reality it requires applying for an e-visa. Unfortunately, I only found this when I was doing my check-in - Saturday, exactly 12 hours before my flight, a bit late right? I immediately applied for an e-visa but given that it was a Saturday I had to wait till Monday for a resolution. Don't get me wrong, the e-visa process is really good and fast but you can't expect much when you end up applying for it too late.

The adventure only starts here...I joined the first event remotely, from Madrid. Once I receive the e-visa approval, I had 4.5 hours to catch the next plane leaving Madrid heading to India. The second event, I also joined it remotely, but this time from Abu Dhabi. The plane touched ground at 06:35, after going through security, I immediate started searching for a quiet place to join the 2nd CodeJam of the week. Fortunately, I found one :-). Straight after the event, I boarded a plane to Hyderabad - not kidding, I was walking to the gate as we were wrapping up the event. I closed my laptop a minute before boarding. Finally, I made it to Hyderabad Tuesday night and I was able to join the last three events in-person. I sincerely want to apologise to the attendees of the first two events as I wasn't able to be there in-person but it was great meeting you virtually; also, doing the event remotely would have not been possible if it wasn't for the great help and support from @ajay_soreng and @Shilpa_Shankar - Thanks to you both!

Apart from the physical badges (stickers) that many of the attendees got. All attendees of the different SAP CodeJams will get a special SAP Community badge for attending the events 🪪.

 

Mumbai

In Mumbai we did the Connecting systems and services using SAP Integration Suite CodeJam at Colgate office. Thanks Colgate for hosting!

We recently introduced a new exercise where we interact with Slack and send notifications from Cloud Integration to Slack. It was exciting to see many attendees posting their notifications even after the event finished.

Hyderabad

In Hyderabad it was all about SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. We ran the Event-driven integrations CodeJam at two different locations. Thanks Mindset and Infosys for hosting the events. I joined the first one remotely from Abu Dhabi and finally in-person for the second event. 

Bengaluru

Last city part of the SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow. At Bengaluru, we ran the new SAP Build: Event-based processes and also the Connecting systems and services with SAP Integration Suite CodeJams at SAP Labs Bengaluru and Mindset Consulting, thanks for hosting. We were fortunate enough to be joined by the entire SAP Developer Advocates team based in India ( @sheenamk, @eshrinivasan, @Rekha_DR, @Shilpa_Shankar), as well as by @acharyaw - PM for SAP Build Process Automation.

 

Food

Last but certainly not least... all the lovely food that we enjoyed as part of the roadshow. Thanks to all the hosts.... the food was amazing everywhere haha.

Lots of lessons learned from the mental misstep and there might be cool things and opportunities coming up thanks to it. Also, this wouldn't have been possible without @ajay_soreng's help organising the events and supporting me while I was remotely - Thanks!
